raw_text:
Chelsea clinch cup in extra-time
 
 (after extra-time - score at 90 mins 1-1)
 
 John Arne Riise volleyed Liverpool ahead after 45 seconds but Steven Gerrard scored a 79th-minute own goal. Blues boss Jose Mourinho was sent off for taunting Liverpool fans after the goal and he watched on television as his side went on to win the game. Drogba and Kezman scored from close range before Antonio Nunez's header made for a tense finale. It was an amazing climax which gave Mourinho his first silverware as Chelsea manager. Yet it was controversial too, after Mourinho's sending off, apparently for putting his finger to his lips to hush the Liverpool fans. There was no hushing them after the extraordinary opening in which the Reds took a stunning lead inside the first minute.
 
 Riise could not have connected any better with Morientes' cross as he smashed a left-foot volley past Petr Cech. The goal, the quickest-ever in a League Cup final, stunned a Blues side whose previously rock-solid confidence had been shaken by consecutive losses to Newcastle and Barcelona in the previous week. The Blues' attacking chances were limited, and Jerzy Dudek was equal to Frank Lampard's powerfully-struck drive and Drogba's low shot. Despite their frustration, Chelsea began to dominate midfield without seriously threatening to break Liverpool's well-organised defence.
 
 Joe Cole had a shot blocked and a promising Damien Duff break was halted by a good tackle from Djimi Traore, but the Reds reached half-time without any major scares. The Blues began the second half with more urgency and pegged Liverpool back. Nevertheless, Liverpool were living dangerously and they needed a fantastic double save from Dudek on 54 minutes, first at full stretch from Gudjohnsen's header, then to smother William Gallas' follow-up. And despite Chelsea's possession, it was Liverpool who fashioned the next clear opportunity as Luis Garcia fed Dietmar Hamann whose shot forced a superb save from Cech. And the Blues' increasingly adventurous approach saw Liverpool earn another chance on the break on 75 minutes as Paulo Ferreira denied Gerrard with a last-ditch tackle. But Gerrard was on the scoresheet minutes later - in the most unfortunate fashion - as he inadvertently deflected Ferrerira's free-kick past his own keeper and in off the post to bring Chelsea level. That prompted Mourinho's reaction which saw him sent off, but Chelsea still pressed and Duff had a chance to win the game with seven minutes remaining. Dudek saved bravely at the Irishman's feet, while Milan Baros shot wildly at the other end to ensure extra time. Drogba almost headed Chelsea in front two minutes into extra-time but the striker saw the ball rebound off the post. But seconds after the half-time interval, Drogba made no mistake, picking the ball up from Glen Johnson's long throw inside the six-yard box and sidefooting home. And Kezman appeared to have made the game safe as he netted from close range after Gudjohnsen's cross in the 110th minute. There was still drama as Nunez beat Cech to a high ball with six minutes remaining to head his side level, but despite Liverpool's desperate attacks, Chelsea clung on to win.
 
 Dudek, Finnan, Carragher, Hyypia, Traore (Biscan 67), Luis Garcia, Gerrard, Hamann, Riise, Kewell (Nunez 56), Morientes (Baros 74).
 
 Subs Not Used: Pellegrino, Carson.
 
 Hyypia, Traore, Hamann, Carragher.
 
 Riise 1, Nunez 113.
 
 Cech, Paulo Ferreira, Ricardo Carvalho, Terry, Gallas (Kezman 74), Jarosik (Gudjohnsen 45), Lampard, Makelele, Cole (Johnson 81), Drogba, Duff.
 
 Subs Not Used: Pidgeley, Tiago.
 
 Lampard, Kezman, Drogba, Duff.
 
 Gerrard 79 og, Drogba 107, Kezman 112.
 
 78,000
 
 S Bennett (Kent).
llama3.2:1b:
Here is a concise summary of the text in plain text:

Chelsea won the League Cup final with a 1-1 draw against Liverpool after extra-time. John Arne Riise scored for Liverpool within minutes but Steven Gerrard's own goal in the 79th minute gave Chelsea the lead. Drogba and Kezman scored from close range, while Antonio Nunez equalized just before halftime. In the second half, Jerzy Dudek made several crucial saves to deny Liverpool, including a spectacular header from Luis Garcia and a follow-up save on William Gallas. Despite Gerrard's equalizer, Chelsea pressed for an extra-time winner and were rewarded when Drogba scored from Glen Johnson's long throw in the 107th minute.
llama3.2:3b: Chelsea won the League Cup final after a dramatic extra-time goal from Didier Drogba. Liverpool took an early lead through John Arne Riise's volley but Steven Gerrard scored an own goal in the 79th minute. Chelsea equalized and the game went to extra time, where Drogba scored the winning goal just two minutes into the second half of extra-time. The match ended with Antonio Nunez equalizing for Liverpool six minutes later, but Chelsea held on to win, securing their first League Cup title under manager Jose Mourinho.
gemma2:2b: Chelsea won the League Cup after extra time against Liverpool, 4-3. Despite an early goal from Riise, Chelsea fought back and took a lead with Drogba and Kezman goals. Gerrard accidentally scored an own goal that sparked controversy as Jose Mourinho was sent off for taunting Liverpool fans.  In the second half, both teams had chances, but Chelsea ultimately dominated to win in extra time.
qwen2.5:0.5b:
Here is the summary in plain text:

Chelsea secured their second League Cup victory with a dramatic extra-time comeback, winning by two goals at 90 minutes. John Arne Riise netted Chelsea's opener, followed by Steven Gerrard and Drogba scoring Liverpool's equalizer late in the game.

Riise's volley was controversial after his side had already conceded points from previous weeks' losses to Newcastle and Barcelona. However, it turned out to be a crucial moment for Chelsea, who managed to maintain their confidence despite facing pressure from Liverpool, whose attacking prowess impressed the crowd.

The Blues dominated midfield without major issues and took control of possession early in the second half. Despite Liverpool's desperate attempts, Chelsea continued pressing and made three clear chances at halftime: one by Luis Garcia on 54 minutes; another by Damien Duff seven minutes later; and a third by Paulo Ferreira with just six minutes remaining.

In extra-time, Kezman struck twice from close range as he scored two goals. The game came down to the final whistle, where Diego Costa's penalty was saved by goalkeeper Petr Cech. However, the Blues dominated throughout the remainder of extra time, leading 3-1 at halftime and securing their third straight win in London.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Chelsea won the Premier League Cup after extra-time thanks to a controversial win following Jose Mourinho's sending-off. Liverpool scored first but Chelsea recovered to level with two goals from Drogba and substitute Kezman before Nunez equalised late on. Chelsea goalkeeper Claudio Bravo was sent off for taunting Liverpool fans, sparking controversy. The game became tense as the teams traded chances, with Liverpool's Luis Garcia goal disallowed after a poor tackle by Djimi Traore. Chelsea dominated in possession but struggled to break through Liverpool's solid defense.
qwen2.5:3b: Chelsea won the cup final in extra time after leveling at 1-1 with a goal from Kezman and leveling on an own goal by Gerrard. The match started poorly for Chelsea as John Arne Riise scored a quick goal and Steven Gerrard made another, leading to Mourinho's dismissal for taunting Liverpool fans. Despite Mourinho's absence, Chelsea dominated the second half but needed extra time after Gudjohnsen's penalty was saved by Petr Cech. Drogba and Kezman scored near the end to ensure Chelsea won 2-1.
opencoder:1.5b:
Chelsea clinched the cup in extra-time with a stunning lead that culminated in a win over Liverpool on Wednesday night. The team faced intense defeat from Newcastle and Barcelona during the League Cup final, which led to impressive victories for both teams.

The match lasted until 90 minutes, with a remarkable opener by Liverpool's Damien Duff and Gerrard's Antonio Nunez, who were separated by more than twenty minutes. Drogba scored from close range before the ball went over the New Year's goalpost and deflected it in two attempts. Despite the intense attacking pressure, Drogba allowed Liverpool to control the moment with a decisive save.

Liverpool also secured another chance on the break at 75 minutes after Gerrard intercepted Ferrerira's free-kick. The Blues managed to earn another chance by closing out the game on 85 minutes while serving a double clear from Dudek's header. Liverpool also faced intense defense, with a series of saves and dribbles thrown into the mix.

Celestial moments included the arrival of Spanish goalkeeper Jose Mourinho and his side's victory in the final round. Liverpool were also forced to make another attempt at 54 minutes when they successfully blocked Damien Duff's save from Cech. This was followed by a fantastic double save from Traore, who took the ball past Gudjohnsen's header.

In the end, Liverpool scored a remarkable 79 goals while Chelsea and Swansea City tied the title with a stunning loss to Newcastle on Tuesday night. The match also featured a 78,000 point goal difference, which is a testament to the team's impressive defensive prowess.
smollm:1.7b:
The summary is concise and to the point, preserving key ideas and details while omitting unnecessary information. The text highlights the main points of the original text:

1. Chelsea clinch cup in extra-time
2. John Arne Riise volleyed Liverpool ahead after 45 seconds but Steven Gerrard scored a 79th-minute own goal.
3. Blues boss Jose Mourinho was sent off for taunting Liverpool fans after the goal and he watched on television as his side went on to win the game.
4. Chelsea won the cup in extra time, with John Arne Riise volleying Liverpool ahead after 45 seconds but Steven Gerrard scoring a 79th-minute own goal.
5. Chelsea's victory was an amazing climax which gave Mourinho his first silverware as manager.
6. The Blues' attacking chances were limited, and Jerzy Dudek was equal to Frank Lampard's powerfully-struck drive when he smashed a left-foot volley past Petr Cech.
7. Chelsea began to dominate midfield without seriously threatening to break Liverpool's well-organised defence.
8. The Blues' possession continued after the second half, but Liverpool were living dangerously and they needed a fantastic double save from Drogba in the 110th minute to head their side level.
9. Dudek saved bravely at the Irishman's feet, while Kezman appeared to have made the game safe as he netted from close range after Gudjohnsen's cross in the 113th minute.
10. The Blues' possession continued until the end of the second half, when Chelsea won the game 78-62.

The summary accurately captures the main points of the original text and provides a concise overview of the key ideas.

tinyllama:1.1b: Chelsea clinches the League Cup after a nail-biting extra-time at Anfield. Despite Liverpool starting the game with more urgency and Chelsea's possession, the Blues began to dominate midfield, scoring a quick goal and dominating the first half. The second half saw a fantastic double save from Dudek on 54 minutes, followed by an impressive free kick from Gerrard. Liverpool's hopes were bleak with Chelsea leveling in extra-time, but they held on to win 2-1 and lift the trophy for their third title in the competition.
tinydolphin:1.1b:
Summarizing the text:

Due to an unfortunate spell of football violence in which Liverpool's players hit Chelsea's defenders with their trunks and were sent off for their actions, Chelsea took an early lead in extra-time. Despite the frustration, they managed to hold on to win a thrilling League Cup final 1-1 against Liverpool. The key figures of this match include Steven Gerrard, who scored a fantastic volley and his teammate John Arne Riise. Chelsea's notable players included Frank Lampard, whose cross led to the opening goal, while Damien Duff and Joe Cole played significant roles in the attack. Liverpool's key player was Michael Carrick and he was booked during extra-time for a provocative challenge on Chelsea defender Glen Johnson. The Reds' key player was Newcastle's striker Martin Hoyland, who scored the decisive goal after his own effort was blocked.

John Arne Riise scored an early goal after just 45 seconds, but Steven Gerrard then scored the first own goal of the game in the 79th minute. Mourinho was sent off for taunting Liverpool fans after the goal. Chelsea went on to score two more goals from Drogba and Kezman, while Djimi Traore made a crucial save in injury time to secure the victory.

granite3.1-dense:2b:
In an intense League Cup final, Liverpool took the lead through John Arne Riise's quick volley in the first minute, marking the fastest goal ever scored in a cup final. Despite Chelsea dominating possession and numerous chances, including Steven Gerrard's controversial own goal, the match remained 1-0 at half-time due to Frank Lampard's powerful shot being saved by Jeremy Jenkins (Petr Cech).

The second half saw a more cautious Liverpool approach, with Chelsea increasing their pressure. Gerrard's unintentional own goal levelled the score in the 79th minute after a defensive error. Following his sending off for taunting Liverpool fans, manager Jose Mourinho watched as Chelsea secured victory through Didier Drogba and Salomon Kezman goals from close range. Antonio Nunez's late header narrowed the gap but ultimately, Chelsea held on to claim their first silverware under Mourinho. The match drew a crowd of 78,000 at Stamford Bridge.
